The concept of 'New Year, New Financial Goals'
is more than just a catchy phrase; it’s an
invitation to rethink and revitalise how we
manage our finances. If you often find yourself
revisiting the same financial goals year after
year, you’re not alone. It’s natural to consider
financial improvements as the new year begins,
but turning those intentions into tangible
change is another matter.
Now, here’s the simple truth: big goals often
stem from small changes in our habits. So, as we
step into 2025 with a few unchecked boxes
from last year, let’s focus on the small
adjustments that not only shape our goals but
also influence our finances in ways that can
make a significant difference. Here are five
ways to improve your finances in the new year:
1. Practice mindful spending

1. Practice mindful spending
It’s all about hitting pause before making that
purchase, especially during promotional sales.
Take a moment to reflect on what you're buying
and whether it aligns with your needs and
budget. Similarly, resist the urge to follow trends
and make purchases simply because they’re
popular. Adopting this subtle shift in mindset
can be a game-changer for your spending
habits. After all, mindful spending isn’t just
about the numbers; it’s about making choices
that support your financial well-being.

2. Regularly monitor your
finances
Regularly reviewing your finances is a smart way
to ensure you're staying on track. Set aside
some time periodically to take a closer look at
your financial situation. This is your opportunity
to assess your progress and make any necessary
adjustments. Whether it’s reallocating funds in
your budget or tweaking your savings goals,
these check-ins help you maintain control over
your financial journey.
3. Build an emergency fund
Building your savings during the good times for
those unexpected rainy days is one of the best
financial habits to start today. Life often
surprises us with sudden expenses or
unexpected income gaps. Aim to save at least

4. Improve financial literacy
Enhancing financial literacy equips you with the
insights required for informed decision-making,
fostering new saving habits through effective
budgeting, goal setting, risk awareness, debt
management, emergency planning, investment
knowledge, and positive behavioural changes.
Commit to a weekly habit of engaging with
educational resources, such as reading books,
following respected financial blogs, or listening
to informative podcasts.
5. Make EPF as your financial
ally
Have you ever considered how the EPF serves as
a cornerstone for enhancing your financial wellbeing? Within the framework of the EPF, there
are features that contribute to bringing you
closer to your financial goals. Let’s explore how
these factors can support your journey to
achieving your goals:
a) Budgeting and expense tracking
Effective budgeting is a key pillar of financial
success. Start by creating a detailed budget
that outlines your income, expenses, and
savings targets. With user-friendly tools like the
Belanjawanku app by EPF, you can easily
monitor spending habits and pinpoint areas to
cut back, making your financial goals more
achievable.

b) Boost your savings
Easily contribute to your EPF account through
the Voluntary Contribution feature on the KWSP
i-Akaun app, giving you the flexibility to grow
your savings with contributions as little as RM10.
Seize this opportunity to take charge of your
financial future and watch how these small
contributions can lead to substantial growth
over time.
Moreover, you can take advantage our
Voluntary Excess (VE) feature, allowing you to
contribute above the statutory rate, whether
initiated by you or your employer. This option
streamlines your financial planning, eliminates
the need for manual monthly savings, and
ensures consistent contributions.

Optimise EPF savings for
long-term growth with
(almost) zero effort
As part of the government’s efforts to prepare
for our retirement, a portion of our monthly
salary is contributed to the EPF. Typically, this
amount remains untouchable unless special
circumstances arise.
While it may be tempting to withdraw and use
the money for the growing expenses of daily life,
you’ll benefit far more by leaving your savings in
your EPF.
It's important to understand that your savings in
the EPF will continue to grow over time, in
addition to the contributions you make. While it
may not seem like much in the short term, the
compounding effect will steadily increase the
value of your money significantly over time.
This year, it's essential to practise wise financial
habits to achieve and sustain financial success.

gradually building savings, adopting a wellrounded approach to managing your finances is
